question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: For the first part, I think a lot of key tools for estimation that are very widely used in the literature finally clicked, like Maximum Likelihood Estimation (I had read articles were researchers used this method or even applied it myself, without a clear idea of what the machinery behind it was doing). I acquired a clearer sense of what parametric estimation is and offers relative to semi or non-parametric estimation, as well as the link to the material we previously studied between estimation and identification. Finally, I learned what the most sought after characteristics are when choosing a particular estimator for research, and the conditions that have to be met to apply them. The second part was the first time I got a clear sense of time series analysis (I had a course in my undergrad, but I would say this would be my first real treatment of this material). Based on work I've done in past employment, I would say that in general the course provided a sufficiently wide and deep understanding of time series to do analysis on your own, with a clear path to expand on what the course offered (i.e. from ARMA to ARIMA). I also learned how classic results from cross-section (like consistency and asymptotic normality) can be maintained in time series analysis, which is a great example of what can be done when typical conditions are not met.
